awd_titl_txt: Biomechanical Regulation in Human Neural Induction
awd_abstract_narration:
Neural tube defects are among the most common birth defects and affect more than 500,000 infants worldwide each year. Neural tube defects can result in severe health problems, including paralysis of legs, brain damage, and even death. To develop novel approaches for the prevention and diagnosis of neural tube defects, a fundamental understanding of the development of the central nervous system is required. Using animal models, genetic and biochemical factors that regulate neural induction, the first stage of the central nervous system development, have been partially unraveled. Recent studies suggest that the cell fate decision in the neural induction is regulated by biomechanical cues.  This mechanical mechanism is poorly understood and very difficult to study using animal models. This research will build a series of novel cell culture tools to investigate the genetic, biochemical and biomechanical interactions during neural induction. These new tools will provide the ability to perform experiments with lower costs and not using animal subjects to determine the mechanical effects on neural tube formation. Fundamental data on how the mechanical environment of the cells changes their behavior during neural tube development will be collected.   The principal investigator will engage K-12, undergraduate and graduate students with diverse ethnic backgrounds and genders with this interdisciplinary bioengineering research, and encourage them to pursue science and engineering careers.

This project will test the hypothesis that mechanical interactions dictate morphogenic events in neural development. Micropatterned cell culture environments are known to cause human cells to mimic the spatial patterning of neuroepithelial cells and neural plate border cells of the neural plate, and thus will be used to model neural induction. Drug treatment and a novel device which locally expands the cells located in the designated regions of micropatterns to dynamically regulate cell shape and force will be used to investigate how cell spatial patterning in the in vitro neural induction model regulates cell shape and force. The mechanotransduction pathways in neural induction will be investigated, focusing on the functional involvement of YAP, BMP and Wnt signals. Lastly, a radial chemical gradient generation device integrated with the micropatterning platform will be developed to interrogate whether biochemical gradient can also induce cell spatial patterning during neural induction, and whether cell shape and force act downstream of biochemical gradient or work independently to determine lineage specification. Using integrative microsystems with the capability to fine-tune chemical and mechanical environment, this research provides for the first time a quantitative analysis of the interactions between biochemical and biomechanical cues in neural development.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The human brain is developed from embryonic tissue termed neural plate. The embryonic cells in the neural plate differentiate into different cell fates depending on their positions. Unsuccessful cell fate patterning will lead to severe birth defects or death. However, little is known about how such cell fate patterning is regulated. Emerging evidence shows that in addition to biochemical cues, biomechanical factors such as cell shape and forces generated by cells also contribute to this cell fate patterning. Through this project, we have developed a cell-based model to study this cell fate patterning process and revealed the interactions between biochemical and biomechanical cues in cell fate patterning.

Intellectual Merit Outcome: Using human embryos to study human development is extremely challenging due to the technical and ethical barriers. In this project, we developed an innovative platform using micropatterned substrates to provide a geometrically confined culture of human pluripotent stem cells. We successfully identified protocols to generate neuroectodermal tissues that mimic the neural plate. Importantly, our studies confirmed that the reaction-diffusion of biomolecules is the main mechanism that is responsible for the cell fate patterning. The biomechanical forces differentials introduced by tissue confinement not only regulate the activation of certain signaling pathways but also change the initial conditions of the system. Our cell-based model can not only mimic the development of the neural plate, but also have the potential to test the effects of environmental toxins and drugs on early brain development.

Broader Impact Outcome: Our results will have a direct impact on the developmental biology field, as the role of mechanical factors is largely underestimated previously. The micropatterned surface, gradient generation device and DNA-based force sensors developed in this project are useful for other researchers in the mechanobiology community. During our research, we have expanded our patterned culture system for other applications such as tumor cell fusion assay and cytotoxicity assay. The results have been disseminated to the research community and general public by journal publications and conference presentations.

In this project, we engaged students from different educational levels and genders, and ethnicities. The project has supported 2 graduate students, 14 undergraduate students, including 7 female and 3 URM students for conducting research in the lab. These students were trained with skills in microfabrication, stem cell biology, microscopy, and data analysis. Some of the research results have also been used in our outreach activities in collaboration with local public schools. Exposing these students to exciting, real-world research topics will stimulate their interest to pursue STEM disciplines. Lastly, we have developed a new interdisciplinary course in molecular, cellular, and tissue biomechanics for the College of Engineering at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. This course has attracted students from different backgrounds (mechanical engineering, biomedical engineering, and cell biology) and prepares senior undergraduate students and graduate students for conducting research in multi-disciplinary areas such as bioengineering. 

 


Last Modified: 10/08/2021
Modified by: Yubing Sun
